I have understood and I agree
This is an agreement for the use of this application between You (The User) and the “HIV RISK Calculator” development team (Us).\n \n
You agree that you will use the application only if you have are of legal age for this kind of content and if this content is legal according to your country and jurisdiction.\n\n
You agree that this application will make a risk estimate for guidance and information purposes, this application does not perform diagnosis nor replaces the assistance of health providers.\n\n

You agree that this application takes as reference current scientific guides and recommendations of international organizations without any ideological bias, however, new scientific knowledge is obtained every day, that’s why we are not responsible for the accuracy of the content.\n\n

You agree that the information and calculations presented by this application are for educational purposes, thereby, we do not assume any responsibility for the consistency of this information with the opinion or diagnosis of health providers.\n\n

You agree that the information and calculations presented by this application are for educational purposes, thereby, we do not assume any responsibility for the consistency of this information with the opinion or diagnosis of health providers.\n\n
This application does not collect any personal information. If you decide to, your result would be sent anonymously for statistical analysis.\n\n
You agree that in order to use this application you should have acquired it from an application online store and will operate under its terms.\n\n
1. You are of legal age for viewing this content.
2. This application does not perform diagnosis nor substitutes medical care.
3. Reliable scientific information and current, but is subject to change
4. We are not responsible for your results.
5. Use the app under your own responsibility.
6. Privacy: No personal data will be collected.

This app will estimate the risk you have for getting HIV (AIDS) through sexual activities and will advise you about what to do to prevent getting an infection or diagnose it promptly based on international scientific standards. This guide does not substitute professional advisory.
Penis to penis rubbing and docking
Where and How to get tested
We used condom or other barrier method correctly
Liked this app? Tell your friends!
Assuming that your partner were HIV positive, your risk for getting HIV is:
Assuming that you were HIV positive, your partner\'s risk for getting HIV is:
The risk of getting infected is enough to do something. Don\'t let it go! You can also have fun with safe sex.
You are at considerable risk of getting HIV infection
Your sexual partner is at considerable risk of getting infection
Other sexual transmitted diseases you may also get:
Is well known that through this activity, HIV virus can be transmitted. The risk cannot be ignored.
Performing this activity is very likely to transmit HIV virus. Although infection is not a certainty, chances of getting infected are high.
There are extremely rare reported cases of HIV transmission through this activity. It\'s very unlikely to happen, but it could.
So far, there is no scientific evidence showing that this activity may transmit HIV virus

A perfectly used condom is effective for avoiding the HIV transmission. The condom efficiency has been widely proven when used consistently. However, you have to take in mind that a minimal risk is always present because you can misuse the condom or it may result to be broken. Other barrier methods have proven to be effective as well, although they haven\'t been studied so widely.
So far, HIV virus transmission during this activity has never been reported although under certain conditions the transmission could be possible.
The chances of getting infected are high, do not ignore the risk and have always safe sex.
You are at high risk of getting HIV infection
Your sexual partner is at high risk of getting infection
Ok, it\'s low, but don\'t take chances. Always prefer safe sex.
You are at low risk of getting HIV infection
Your sexual partner is at low risk of getting infection
So far, there is no scientific evidence showing that the activities you have performed can let to an HIV infection.
You are at no risk of getting HIV infection
Your sexual partner is at no risk of getting HIV infection
¡Excellent! Keep having safe sex and make your partner do the same.

Having safe sex (protected) is the best thing you can do to prevent HIV infection or other STDs. Besides condom, other barrier methods can reduce HIV transmission risk for almost every sexual activity. Being regularly tested for HIV and other STDs and going to your health providers is widely recommended.

A perfectly used condom is effective for avoiding the HIV transmission. The condom efficiency has been widely proven when used consistently. However, you have to take in mind that a minimal risk is always present because you can misuse the condom or it may result to be broken.

The use of latex dams (dental dams) is useful to reduce the risk of getting HIV and other STDs while performing this activity, although its protective effect has not been studied so deeply. Condoms cut lengthwise are also useful for reducing the risk.
The use of latex medical gloves are useful to reduce the risk of getting HIV and other STDs while performing this activity, although its protective effect has not been studied so deeply.
What protective methods can I use?
But, what if my partner is HIV positive and is receiving treatment?
But, what if I am HIV positive and currently receiving treatment?

Recent finding suggest that if your partner, had been receiving and adequate and successful antiretroviral therapy with undetectable viral load, the risk you have for getting infection lowers up to 90%. However, this doesn\'t mean that you are at no risk at all, that\'s why is always preferable the correct use of condom during sexual intercourse. If your on a stable partnership consult your health provider for knowing more about having sexual a safe sexual life with your partner.

Recent finding suggest that if you had been receiving and adequate and successful antiretroviral therapy with undetectable viral load, your partner\'s risk for getting infection lowers up to 90%. However, this doesn\'t mean that your partner has no risk at all, that\'s why is always preferable the correct use of condom during sexual intercourse. If your on a stable partnership consult your health provider for knowing more about having sexual a safe sexual life with your partner.
Things that may increase the risk

Having sex with too many partners increases the risk of getting HIV or other STD infections. Furthermore, if you do not know your partner or is a casual partner, or if the intercourse happened in a hookup place, the risk gets even higher. Having skin or mucosal injuries also increase the risk.
Should I have to take the HIV test?
Should my partner be tested for HIV?
An HIV test is recommended in no more than 6 months, specially if you have more sexual partners. You should also go to your health professional for guidance about other STDs testing.
Is recommended for your partner to have an HIV test in no more than 6 months, and should also look for medical guidance about other STDs.

You should get the HIV test promptly! after this, you have to go to your health professional. Nevertheless, if the intercourse happened in less than a week, you should visit your health professional before getting tested.

Make your partner being tested as soon as possible, after this, your partner has to go to a health professional. However, if the intercourse happened in less than a week, your partner needs to go to a health professional before getting tested.
A yearly HIV test is recommended at least if you perform this activities often
Is recommended for your partner to have an annual test at least.
You don\'t need to regarding these sexual activities.
Your partner doesn\'t has to be tested regarding these sexual activities
You don\'t need to regarding these sexual activities. However, if you had sex more than one sexual partners, a yearly HIV test is recommended.
Is recommended for your partner to have an annual test at least.
Although the risk of infection is very low, you should always prefer safe sex.
You are at very low risk of getting HIV infection
Your sexual partner is at very low risk of getting infection

Parasitosis like: Amebiasis, Shigellosis, Giardiasis and Hepatitis A
Thank you for using this app!

1. Check expiration date, if it has expired, replace it.
 2. Use a new condom for every act or intercourse, from start to end.
 3. Put a condom on the erect penis before any contact is made between any part of partner's body
 4. Holding the tip of the condom, unroll it all the way down to the base of the penis
 5. After ejaculation and before penis gets soft, withdraw carefully the condom avoiding semen leaks
 6. Dispose the condom immediately wrapping it in tissue 
 7. If you felt the condom broke, stop immediately, withdraw and replace it. 
 8. Be sure lubrication is enough during intercourse, if not, use water based lubricants

Other barrier devices for sex such as female condom, dental latex dams or latex gloves are effective reducing the risk of HIV transmission as long as they are perfectly used and they cover all contacting and infecting areas such as mouth, genitals or anus. However there is no enough scientific data to be sure this methods are as effective as condom.
